Hi! Great questions! I am no spokesperson for the  project, but I do think I can provide possible explanations for these behaviors:


The first case I believe is an internet-connectivity check. I do agree the rate and an option to toggle it completely would be useful.

Maybe even the target should be configurable, www.yahoo.com may not be responsive forever. Also in a large private network environment one may want VPN to segregate further but the entire network is incapable of reaching yahoo it makes no sense to attempt to but perhaps it does make sense to hit some other internal endpoint instead. Configurability would be great there.



To the second case


https://github.com/SoftEtherVPN/SoftEtherVPN/blob/0b8fcb75bc577847af2405d7dfc87cdc3945ad89/src/Mayaqua/Internat.c#L2046-L2048

The warning page could be quite concerting! But I think both cases are benign. I would presume the latter one is due to as it claims, actual legal involvement requiring some form of warning and liability release. I would propose adding code to enable compiling it out, but I could see in that case that releasing SoftEther with the ability to compile WITHOUT that code in would be flagrant violation of whatever happened, at least as long as the public SoftEther purported to run the same code base. So in the worst case if you really distrust it you can always fork and disable I guess.

I hope my answers make sense and someone with more authority can come in and give better answers. :).

cd ~/source
git clone https://github.com/SoftEtherVPN/SoftEtherVPN.git
cd SoftEtherVPN/src/Mayaqua
mv Network.c Network.c.orig
cat Network.c.orig | sed ‘s!SSLv3_method!SSLv23_client_method!g’ > Network.c
cd ../..
./configure
make.

I found this discussion, which seems to imply that it IS indeed possible to split traffic and assign priorities.... I'm just not sure HOW this is actually accomplished!?!
https://community.spiceworks.com/topic/435226-softether-for-business-use-open-source-vpn
~~~
The Brentmeister General
Poblano
The Brentmeister General Apr 26, 2015 at 7:47 PM 
We are in the same boat as Nurul3751. How do you get split 
tunnelling working? Has anyone managed it?
SoftEther VPN seems an ideal solution for us but, until 
we can enable split tunnelling so regular
 traffic isn't slowed to a crawl, we don't feel we can 
deploy it. (Other than this, it is absolutely 
brilliant.)
Here is the impact on our speed test results as a result
 of our regular web traffic going over the SoftEther VPN link:
Ping increases from 5 ms -> 100 ms
DL decreases from 26 Mbps -> 0.59 Mbps
UP decreases from 2.69 Mbps -> 0.49 Mbps
The difference is obvious even when performing 
bandwidth-light tasks such as using a search
 engine - very laggy. For slightly more bandwidth-intensive 
tasks, such as streaming a video on
 YouTube, there is so much buffering that it renders it unwatchable.
Any ideas?
UPDATE:
I found out how to do this: it was related to the 
configuration of the SoftEther VPN client machine.
We changed the subnet of our satellite sites so 
different to main office, then was able to specify
 different default gateways for the physical NIC 
and VPN virtual NIC. Interface metric set to "1" for
 physical NIC and "100" for virtual NIC, so only
 uses that as a last resort (i.e. when accessing 
server shares).
~~~.

Done. Pushed the fixes in a new commit (068094f). PreverifyOk was indeed not used; removed it.. A private key file contains several numbers (modulus, private exponent, public exponent etc), and not all of them are used in all operations. So you can, indeed, change some numbers without affecting the ability to sign or decrypt with the private key. For example:
```
$ diff -u steve.key x_steve.key
--- steve.key   2017-05-26 20:40:29.000000000 +0300
+++ x_steve.key 2018-04-05 09:25:52.588306375 +0300
@@ -7,7 +7,7 @@
 xNU1BO6m0h/5A5mtUy0nk4f9MdxAXXBN1yRvQ7M6qAxXN7sw5lH14mlfpKgPq+VM
 DtUgGFkPgaLPEW38mQJBAPXtFoyjwEfAPq3ZPcOWohq0+lqSu4Oh8SI0HTz4vZGn
 7V7lSDcCuEV/DReEmPt9h88Yi3l8bwZeyhYZOKq9CI8CQQD09zWAYCLSSJ7OyazG
-HQvW5kI+MBLRj9D9kZlDUME4A30NgricYO6n0R8NL6LMIPjxaWfqpqClzet+Z2bD
+HQvW5kI+mBLRj9D9kZlDUME4A30NgricYO6n0R8NL6LMIPjxaWfqpqClzet+Z2bD
 Z4SnAkEAzIGbZdrqlAA/X0yvew2xwinLozQwMRejMYFK6yAibJTL5UUf13cwi8JK
 vcrreP97x3Eu0xjyLsb2oIfawskt6wJAKtXfoScub58LRhW2BJ6np1h0VPOLFuIT
 JYQETOUeJHFXuLkXFyFMGkRTLbcavJ83aN+JsFqa1OOBPoVOTvUXGQJBAMEi+g6b
$ openssl rsa -noout -check -in steve.key
RSA key ok
$ openssl rsa -noout -check -in x_steve.key
RSA key error: q not prime
RSA key error: n does not equal p q
RSA key error: d e not congruent to 1
RSA key error: dmq1 not congruent to d
RSA key error: iqmp not inverse of q
$ openssl rsa -noout -modulus -in steve.key | md5sum
9991b79bdbf3ca869c82b9a1b5ad7141  -
$ openssl rsa -noout -modulus -in x_steve.key | md5sum
9991b79bdbf3ca869c82b9a1b5ad7141  -
$ openssl dgst -sha256 -sign steve.key -out /tmp/signature.steve.sha256 /tmp/signed_data
$ openssl dgst -sha256 -sign x_steve.key -out /tmp/signature.x_steve.sha256 /tmp/signed_data
$ ls -al /tmp/.sha256
-rw-rw-r-- 1 alexey alexey 128 Apr  5 09:33 /tmp/signature.steve.sha256
-rw-rw-r-- 1 alexey alexey 128 Apr  5 09:33 /tmp/signature.x_steve.sha256
$ md5sum /tmp/.sha256
cac540cb0955e8ab4ab6a39c282afdbe  /tmp/signature.steve.sha256
cac540cb0955e8ab4ab6a39c282afdbe  /tmp/signature.x_steve.sha256
$ openssl dgst -sha256 -verify <(openssl x509 -in steve.crt -pubkey -noout) -signature /tmp/signature.steve.sha256 /tmp/signed_data
Verified OK
$ openssl dgst -sha256 -verify <(openssl x509 -in steve.crt -pubkey -noout) -signature /tmp/signature.x_steve.sha256 /tmp/signed_data
Verified OK
```
As you can see, even though the damaged private key file does not pass the openssl rsa -check test, it still has the same modulus value as the original, and it produces the same signature as the original key. This damaged file can also be successfully used by OpenVPN client, as you have noted. This is a (mis)feature of the OpenSSL implementation.
SoftEther VPN Server, in its role as SSL/TLS server, does not, of course, get to see the client's private key, so cannot verify its integrity (as openssl rsa -check does). Server only sees that the client, when prompted during the handshake, has produced the correct signature which matches the certificate; so the client must possess the correct private key and therefore should be successfully authenticated.
Now let's try and change some other character in the private key:
```
$ diff -u steve.key y_steve.key
--- steve.key   2017-05-26 20:40:29.000000000 +0300
+++ y_steve.key 2018-04-05 09:59:23.214988138 +0300
@@ -1,6 +1,6 @@
 -----BEGIN PRIVATE KEY-----
 MIICdwIBADANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQEFAASCAmEwggJdAgEAAoGBAOtTdKQ2VgMVIQtk
-qEhwYgBuorup9jdSiUEuP8N+3U+c16JZ6JpfG+nZfa2TFfzylw1N3yfGqMIa0XGa
+qEhwYgBuoUup9jdSiUEuP8N+3U+c16JZ6JpfG+nZfa2TFfzylw1N3yfGqMIa0XGa
 j5ljVab0SbfM1L9RAeo1wf7nfAvJmNSirxGsVlgaQlVyvzRkBHJ5szrqJmv6xcNi
 C0fcYmSjhQ3eqp+a0hprTY44Q1FJAgMBAAECgYAgkWY9K7/voUb3erDHhbYqdSVU
 b4tB0MxqFuqANdiPIhe9wk+svajxTkZUdVy/qxs4niRaLuZAJtIBtPBWvCaoNoqw
$ openssl rsa -noout -check -in y_steve.key
RSA key error: n does not equal p q
$ openssl rsa -noout -modulus -in x_steve.key | md5sum
9991b79bdbf3ca869c82b9a1b5ad7141  -
$ openssl rsa -noout -modulus -in y_steve.key | md5sum
a896af578f40204c9015617f129b1603  -
$ openssl dgst -sha256 -sign y_steve.key -out /tmp/signature.y_steve.sha256 /tmp/signed_data
$ md5sum /tmp/*.sha256
cac540cb0955e8ab4ab6a39c282afdbe  /tmp/signature.steve.sha256
cac540cb0955e8ab4ab6a39c282afdbe  /tmp/signature.x_steve.sha256
ff6b1284d6585aa1a88f6af25fb9a1e0  /tmp/signature.y_steve.sha256
$ openssl dgst -sha256 -verify <(openssl x509 -in steve.crt -pubkey -noout) -signature /tmp/signature.y_steve.sha256 /tmp/signed_data
Verification Failure
```
Aha! Now it is really broken.
In this case OpenVPN client itself recognizes that the key is broken and prevents us from using it:
$ openvpn y_steve.ovpn
Thu Apr  5 10:05:35 2018 OpenVPN 2.3.2 x86_64-pc-linux-gnu [SSL (OpenSSL)] [LZO] [EPOLL] [PKCS11] [eurephia] [MH] [IPv6] built on Jun 22 2017
Thu Apr  5 10:05:35 2018 WARNING: No server certificate verification method has been enabled.  See http://openvpn.net/howto.html#mitm for more info.
Thu Apr  5 10:05:35 2018 Cannot load private key file y_steve.key: error:0B080074:x509 certificate routines:X509_check_private_key:key values mismatch
Thu Apr  5 10:05:35 2018 Error: private key password verification failed
Thu Apr  5 10:05:35 2018 Exiting due to fatal error
What would happen if OpenVPN client did not perform such validation? During SSL/TLS handshake the client would fail to produce a signature that can be verified with the client's certificate / public key (as we have demonstrated above), and the handshake would fail.. I have made a quick fix in #476. It compiles with OpenSSL 1.0.1 (the older one), and should compile with 1.1.0, but I have no access to 1.1.0 at the moment and cannot verify it myself right now. Could you guys please test it with 1.1.0?. I agree to changing the license.. Fixed the line break, but static_cast would not work here, because Network.c is not complied as a C++ source file:
...
cc -DNDEBUG -DVPN_SPEED -DUNIX -DUNIX_LINUX -DCPU_64 -D_REENTRANT -DREENTRANT -D_THREAD_SAFE -D_THREADSAFE -DTHREAD_SAFE -DTHREADSAFE -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 -I./src/ -I./src/Cedar/ -I./src/Mayaqua/
 -O2 -fsigned-char -m64 -c src/Mayaqua/Network.c -o tmp/objs/Mayaqua/Network.o
src/Mayaqua/Network.c: In function 'SslCertVerifyCallback':
src/Mayaqua/Network.c:5825:29: error: 'static_cast' undeclared (first use in this function)
   clientcert->PreverifyOk = static_cast<bool>(preverify_ok);. Removed this line altogether, since, as you correctly noted, the value assigned to PreverifyOk is never used.. Should also remove the corresponding #define from Mayaqua/Mayaqua.h:218. Copy seems unnecessary: EVP_EncryptInit_ex signature has a const modifier for iv parameter. Same applies to plaintext and EVP_EncryptUpdate call below. Also, same applies to AesDecrypt function.. Should call EVP_CIPHER_CTX_free(ctx) before returning from the function (here and in several places below). Same applies to AesDecrypt function.. Is the copy operation necessary here? Why not pass dest directly to EVP_EncryptUpdate / EVP_EncryptFinal_ex instead of ciphertext?. The comments about freeing ctx before returns and unnecessary Copying also apply to this function.. Docs state "the decrypted data buffer out passed to EVP_DecryptUpdate() should have sufficient room for (inl + cipher_block_size) bytes". See also https://github.com/opendnssec/SoftHSMv2/issues/169.
(Note that this requirement is probably to handle the padding, and with the way AesDecrypt is used in SoftEther codebase, no padding is needed). EVP_EncryptFinal_ex adds so-called PKCS padding to the ciphertext. This padding is always at least one byte long. But the ciphertext array (declared on line 4636) has the same size as the plaintext, with no space reserved for padding, so buffer overflow occurs here.
Note that the AES_cbc_encrypt function which was previously used here does not add PKCS padding (see here for reference), so the new code is not equivalent to the earlier version.
Also note that the only caller of AesEncrypt (Cedar/IPsec_IkePacket.c) performs its own padding operation: in IkeEncryptWithPadding() the plaintext length is rounded up to a nearest block boundary, and the ciphertext is then expected to be the same size.
Therefore I suggest removing the EVP_EncryptFinal_ex call (and its counterpart EVP_DecryptFinal_ex call from AesDecrypt) and adding an assertion size % AES_BLOCK_SIZE == 0  to the beginning of AesEncrypt.
EDIT: a better way would be to disable the padding with a EVP_CIPHER_CTX_set_padding call, instead of removing EVP_EncryptFinal_ex.
Another option would be to make AesEncrypt a more general-purpose function which can handle arbitrary plaintext lengths. In this case, you'll need to allocate additional space for ciphertext, and rewrite Cedar/IPsec_IkePacket.c to do the same, and make sure that the correct padding is also present when calling AesDecrypt. Though, since IPsec does not use PKCS padding anyway, I'm not sure there is a practical need for this.. If you remove the EVP_EncryptFinal_ex call as I suggested above, this call also should be removed. Otherwise you have to make sure the correct PKCS padding is present in the ciphertext when AesDecrypt is called --- which means adding it manually, because IPsec does not use PKCS padding.
EDIT: better yet, do not remove the EVP_EncryptFinal_ex call and disable the padding with EVP_CIPHER_CTX_set_padding.. Since ctx == NULL here, there is no need to call EVP_CIPHER_CTX_free in this specific place. Same on the line 4679..

In Linux I use SoftEther server soft as server and as client. You create 1. hub 2. bridge tap for hub 3. cascade connection to another server. So it is work around for peer-to-peer. SoftEther client on Linux do nothing to routing table or interface IP. You have to set manually or configure it for static or dhcp network interface.
auto tap_hub1
iface tap_hub1 inet static
    address 192.168.30.2
    netmask 255.255.255.0
auto tap_hub2
iface tap_hub2 inet dhcp
. SoftEther works great with creating tap device and debian/ubuntu network interface config works too. Try this:
```
auto lo
iface lo inet loopback
allow-br0 eth0
iface eth0 inet manual
allow-br0 tap_vpn
iface tap_vpn inet manual
    up brctl addif br0 $IFACE
    pre-down brctl delif br0 $IFACE
auto br0
iface br0 inet static
    bridge_ports eth0
    address 192.168.1.1
    netmask 255.255.255.0
    network 192.168.1.0
    broadcast 192.168.1.255
    gateway 192.168.1.120
. If you will use openvswitch:
allow-vmbr0 eth0
iface eth0 inet manual
    ovs_type OVSPort
    ovs_bridge vmbr0
auto vmbr0
iface vmbr0 inet static
    address 10.10.8.1
    netmask 255.255.248.0
    ovs_type OVSBridge
    ovs_ports eth0
```. I set up /etc/network/interfaces to automatically do something with SoftEther device on creating/destroying.

joshperry:
Hey guys,
The importance of this patch is like @davidebeatrici said, but not just for connectivity detection. All network management scripts on Linux rely on the transitioning of the Up/Down state to know when certain configuration tasks should be done.
For example the dhcpcd client only attempts to allocate/renew a dynamic IP address when the interface transitions from Down to Up. If the state never transitions, and the server (and/or its dhcp server) are recycled, then the client will not allocate a new address until the current one expires. If you do not persist your dhcp leases then your server-side systems will have no idea what IP address to use to communicate with the client.
Another critical aspect is that the Kernel will keep this network segment as part of the system's routing table as long as it is Up. This makes it very difficult to implement features like least-cost or priority routing based on the network metrics if the network is not really Up when it says it is.
Thank you for pushing this forward!

quantum5:
@moatazelmasry2 the list of ciphers are chosen to be in order of security, as typically recommended, preferring authenticated encryption ciphers, while also maintaining compatibility. The intention is that most installations will use these default ciphers and automatically benefit from the increased security should new ciphers be created.
Using the other cipher list would prefer using extremely insecure ciphers like RC4-MD5. I would remove it, but the management tool uses it and I couldn't quite figure out how to modify it.. The main concern regarding configurable ciphers is what happens if the server is misconfigured to use no cipher at all. I decided to use the fallback as a sane alternative, since otherwise a lot of error handline will have to be implemented so some obscure error message doesn't show up.
Admittedly, the invalid specification is a hack, but is probably the best I can do without seriously messing with the management UI. The management program cuts off any long cipher list, which makes it almost impossible to list more than one cipher inside it, hence, a short invalid string has to be used for now.
To do it properly, the UI will have to be a list of checkboxes that can be moved around, or perhaps two lists of ciphers, one for active, and one for inactive, and a button to move ciphers in and out of the list. I am afraid I do not have the time for this.. Also note that OpenSSL will use a default list of ciphers anyway, if it fails to set the cipher list.. No objections to changing the license..

slabber:
Just FYI, it's a bit hackish but you can also put the config file elsewhere by symlinking.  Here's a dockerfile that works fine with a persistent disk in Kubernetes for storing the config:
FROM alpine
ENV LANG en_US.UTF-8
RUN apk update && apk add openssl ncurses readline dumb-init iptables
RUN apk add build-base readline-dev openssl-dev ncurses-dev && \
        wget -qO - http://www.softether-download.com/files/softether/v4.24-9651-beta-2017.10.23-tree/Source_Code/softether-src-v4.24-9651-beta.tar.gz | tar -xzf - && \
        cd v4.24-9651 && \
        ./configure && \
        make install && \
        apk del build-base readline-dev openssl-dev ncurses-dev && \
        cd .. && rm -rf v4.24-9651 && \
        mkdir -p /etc/vpnserver && \
        ln -sf /etc/vpnserver/vpn_server.config /usr/vpnserver/vpn_server.config
VOLUME /etc/vpnserver
EXPOSE 443/tcp
ENTRYPOINT ["/usr/bin/dumb-init", "--"]
CMD ["/bin/sh","-c","touch /etc/vpnserver/vpn_server.conf && exec /usr/vpnserver/vpnserver execsvc"]
.

BUT still nothing about other OS and files.
And even in Windows... What will OS say if file is not signed and unpacked from zip archive? I guess nothing... Even with signing available a user will have to check each file instead of archive with CD (all components). And instead of hash-based integrity (embedded in many file managers) you offer the user to download Windows SDK to get SignTool?
User needs just to be sure that binary is provided by owner of the project! Any signing is just additional step... And it is not considered by 99% of users.
So secure channel is still required... to deliver binaries or deliver hash. 
And for Linux it is the same. For example it can be own repository for each distro and all packages can be signed, but we still need to publish key for repo and provide that info using some secure trusted channel.
I do not think it makes sense to discuss more. I have explained my position well.
If you have opposite thoughts then we need arguments and details.
For now from your posts I can summarize only that "signing is enough to deliver valid binaries to user".
Obviously it is not true. If you have anything to say more than signing - you are welcome.
.

jamesbrink:
I am facing the same issue, looks like there is some kind of limitation of 30 static routes that can be pushed to clients. . So I just wanted to drop a comment in case anyone else comes across this. Due to this change I had to alter my OpenVPN config files. I generally had my softether vpn server setup with multiple routes but I had left the default gateway blank so it would not be used to route internet traffic.
With these changes I started getting the following errors.
OpenVPN ROUTE: vpn_gateway undefined
OpenVPN ROUTE: failed to parse/resolve route for host/network: xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx
I was able to add pull-filter ignore redirect-gateway to my open vpn config files and this resolved the issue and allowed me to continue operating as before..

Fixed. Thanks.. For my records (at some point, I'm going to make this into a script), this is how I performed the Korean bits:
This sets up my histedit:
sh
hg histedit -r '. % master'
^Z (suspend the editor) -- in theory this can be replaced by EDITOR=script (that performs the next command)
This picks all the commits that impacted a parallel file and then rewrites the pick lines as edit:
sh
perl -pi -e 'next unless / '$(hg log -T '{rev}|' -r '. % master'  src/bin/hamcore/strtable_en.stb|sed -e 's/|$//')' /; s/pick/edit/' "/tmp/hg-histedit-tp8NKm.histedit.hg.txt"
Return to and quit the default editor:
fg
:q
This finalizes the current commit; checks to see what the new commit is; and then checks to see what kind of change the current commit is making (is it changing the identifier or changing the translation):
sh
EDITOR=true hg histedit --cont; hg summary; d -U0 strtable_en.stb|grep $(d -U0 strtable_en.stb |rediff|tail -1|sed -e 's/^-//')
This tries to apply the change (including space adjustments-- never relevant for ko, but potentially relevant for other languages; and then a second time w/o space adjustments):
sh
perl -pi -e "$(d -U0 strtable_en.stb|perl -ne 'next unless /^-[^-]|^\+[^+]/; s/(\s+)\S.*/$1/; chomp; s{^-}{s/}; s{^\+(\S+\s*)}{/$1/;}; print')$(d -U0 strtable_en.stb|perl -ne 'next unless /^-[^-]|^\+[^+]/; s/(\s+)\S.*//; chomp; s{^-}{s/}; s{^\+(\S+\s*)}{/$1/;}; print')" strtable_ko.stb; d -U0 strtable_en.stb strtable_ko.stb

thepyper:
Hi!
I've traced back some debugging I did in 2015, here is results of my findings at that time:

The problem lies in InitInternational, it does not couple well with musl iconv support (that is more limited than gnu iconv).
As a reference, you can look into:
http://git.musl-libc.org/cgit/musl/tree/src/locale/iconv.c
In particular:
1) at Internat.c \ line 935, tries to call iconv_open("C", "UTF-16BE");
this fails because "C" has no meaning to musl iconv (at least that seems to me)
2) at Internat.c \ line 943, tries to call iconv_open("EUCJP", "UTF-16BE");
this fails because that combination is not supported (while "EUCJP" and "UTF-16BE" are recognized by musl)
3) at Internat.c \ line 960, tries to call iconv_open("US", "UTF-16BE");
this faile because "US" has no meaning to musl iconv;
there is 2 simple solutions to that problem:
1) use "UTF-8", as is done on MACOSX system, this works with musl (well, it does not block make at least :)
2) use "ASCII" or "USASCII" or "ISO646" or "ISO646US" instead of "US", those should be synonims in musl for "US".
(see line 41 in http://git.musl-libc.org/cgit/musl/tree/src/locale/iconv.c)

don't know if iconv logic changed in-between... 
. Why disabling it, when a simple fix is available?
I'm using softether compiled this way since 2015, and it has no problems on musl...
. Uhm... sorry I'm not understanding exactly :)
Musl is libc implementation, and of course I build softether on alpine linux with gcc (which on alpine uses musl as libc implementation).
I have no issues with musl but I'm no libc expert so cannot judge whenever musl / glibc / newlib / whatever libc is better and why, I just want to compile softether on alpile linux because I like some features of this distro...
Well, whatever :)
I will continue manually patching softether when I compile on musl, no problem. 
Hope you will not change it to completely refuse compiling on musl, or at least keep an "override" option please :)
. This particular issue is only seen at runtime, yes. I spent some time debugging it, basically everything needing a string (all texts) was failing because iconv was not able to convert it; so issue was pretty evident itself :)
I don't want to be pushy, your software your choices: I just tell you that by my experience there is no other known issue on musl; I used both client and server features, and never experienced any strange behaviour.
Second thought is that this fix is not my invention, it's already being used to make softether run correctly on macosX, so it's already "well-tested" I suppose; all I did is to enable inconditionally that fix. A more conservative approach would be, if you can spot musl during cmake phase (I have no cmake experience), to enable the fix only for MUSL, changing line 938 in Internat.c from:
ifdef  UNIX_MACOS
to 
if defined(UNIX_MACOS) || defined(UNIX_MUSL)  (whatever flag reveals musl)
. Problem happens at runtime: the iconv_open call fails (see previous comments for details) during softether initializations.
Then, every time softether tries translating a string, it fails because during initializations iconv_open failed.
Don't remember exactly the behaviour, but was pretty unusable (I mean it was not a subtle but, just nothing worked :). Sure I will do next days when I will be back in office..

2. you would like to mantain current behaviour and change it only for musl.
Option 2 is quite difficult, as musl faq explains:
(see question: Why is there no MUSL macro?)
https://wiki.musl-libc.org/faq.html
http://openwall.com/lists/musl/2013/03/29/13
So there is no easy way to know that compiler is using musl, as musl authors believe that you should not rely on knowing it, as musl is perfect and bug-less :P

kawing-chiu:
Exactly the same problem here. The tcp connection to SQL server dies after around 40 seconds if using softether vpn (with securenat enabled). This issue does not exist if connecting to SQL server directly in LAN, without using softether vpn. Have no idea where this 40 seconds timeout comes from.. I investigated the issue a bit further and captured packets on both the client side and the server side. Due to lack of knowledge in tcp protocol debugging, I am not able to interpret the capture log in detail but it looks suspicious (strangely, this time the connection breaks at around 1 min, not 40 secs).
Here is my setup: 192.168.30.10 is the client 's ip behind SecureNAT 's NAT (SecureNAT's virtual gateway is 192.168.30.1). (Edit: In this test, the securenat function is in user mode). The machine running softether vpn bridge with SecureNAT is 10.38.18.161. And the sql server that the client try to communicate is at 10.38.63.7 port 1433.
The connection worked well at the begining. The client logged in to the sql server and successfully performed a select 1 query. However, after the connection idled for some time, something went wrong and the connection was reset unexpectedly. From some point on, the client sent keepalive to the server at a high frequency and then later reset the connection.

Here are the wireshark capture files:
client_capture.zip server_capture.zip
Edit: Now I know why this test is different from the previous tests (i.e. not break at around 40 secs). This is because in previous tests, the securenat function is in kernel-mode and raw ip mode. While in this test, the seurenat function is in user mode. I did not alter any of the config of SoftEther vpn, but it seems that whether or not to use kernel-mode/raw ip mode nat is chosen somewhat randomly at each boot, this may indicate another bug.
. Now I conduct the same test when securenat is in kernel-mode. The client / server settings is the same as above. This time the connection breaks after idling for about 40 secs. From the capture files, we can see that although the connection just breaks as the previous test, it is of different reason. This time, it is the server that tries to send a lot of keep-alive messages to the client, but failed to get a response, so it cut off the connection.
Here are the wireshark capture files for this second test (securenat in kernel/raw ip mode):
client_capture_2.zip server_capture_2.zip
. To sum up: This bug occurs whether the securenat fucntion is in kernel/raw ip mode or in user mode. While in these two cases the same symptom is exhibited from the user's point of view (connection break up after idling for some time),  it looks quite different at the tcp packet level. Hope this helps to solve the bug..

PaulGWebster:
I cannot seem to reproduce this issue on an LG G6, android version 8.0.0 Kernel version 3.18.71. Confirmed working on FreeBSD 11.2-BETA2 r334022
If the ports version of softether vpn is installed, already you can replace the binaries:
  1138  22:59   cp vpnbridge /usr/local/libexec/softether/vpnbridge
  1142  23:00   cp vpncmd /usr/local/sbin/vpncmd
  1151  23:01   cp vpnclient /usr/local/libexec/softether/vpnclient
  1156  23:01   cp vpnbridge /usr/local/libexec/softether/vpnbridge
and then copy the required hamcore.se2 so the binary directories (should really work from /usr/local/lib but does not):
  1204  23:08   cp hamcore.se2 /usr/local/sbin/
  1210  23:08   cp hamcore.se2 /usr/local/libexec/softether/
Doing so will allow the rc scripts from the ports version to continue working. Tested on: 11.2-STABLE FreeBSD 11.2-STABLE #0 r336751
Build method: Compiled in place as a user and copied the binaries over the older versions created by ports:

cp vpnserver/vpnserver /usr/local/libexec/softether/vpnserver && 
cp vpnclient/vpnclient /usr/local/libexec/softether/vpnclient && 
cp vpnclient/vpnclient /usr/local/libexec/softether/vpnclient && 
cp vpnbridge/vpnbridge /usr/local/libexec/softether/vpnbridge && 
cp vpnclient/hamcore.se2 /usr/local/libexec/softether/ && 
cp vpnclient/hamcore.se2 /usr/local/sbin/

. After another test i got the Openvpn 3 Android app working. With the following changes.
I changed the openvpn config file to have the ca certificate also in the  brackets.
Old config (not working):
```
config stuff....

--ca cert--


--client cert--


--client key--

New config (working):
config stuff....

--ca cert--


--client cert--
--client cert ca--


--client key--

```
Notes:
 In my case the ca cert is the same as the client cert ca.
 This only works if the client cert ca is after the client cert. Like @paskal said I really like the debian package naming.

So, I think you are saying that after I fork, then clone my fork onto my

Correct.
You can also clone this repository and then add yours as new remote.
Now that I have done the pull request on an unbranched clone, how do I fix
that, is there a way to move that to a branch?
You can switch to a new branch with git checkout -b branch-name, however
this pull request is tied to master.
How do I, and should I update my repository to get the line endings
changes?
Since this is a cross-platform project, the right thing to do would be to
convert the line endings to LF for all files.
To keep the commit "clean", I would create a new one which changes the
line endings from CRLF to LF.
In order to do that, you can:
Remove the last commit and keep its changes in the tree
git reset HEAD~
Copy the edited file somewhere
cp src/BuildUtil/VpnBuilder.cs src/BuildUtil/VpnBuilder.cs.new
Restore the original file
git checkout -- src/BuildUtil/VpnBuilder.cs
Change the line endings from CRLF to LF
dos2unix src/BuildUtil/VpnBuilder.cs
Stage changes for the next commit
git add -u
Create commit
git commit -m "BuildUtil/VpnBuilder.cs: change line endings from CRLF to LF"
Move the edited file to the right place
mv src/BuildUtil/VpnBuilder.cs.new src/BuildUtil/VpnBuilder.cs
Stage changes for the next commit
git add -u
Create commit
git commit -m "BuildUtil/VpnBuilder.cs: Fix an issue with building on Visual Studio 2008"
Push branch to the remote (-f specifies "forced", required because we removed a commit)
git push -f

You're welcome.
You changed the line endings correctly, however you did it for the entire
repository.
I propose to:
Switch to a new branch
git checkout -b crlf-to-lf
Remove last commit
git reset --hard HEAD~1
Update previous commit's message (something like "Change line endings from CRLF to LF") and update timestamp (--reset-author does it automatically)
git commit --amend --reset-author
Push the current branch to the remote (-u sets it as upstream. origin is the main remote, which currently corresponds to your forked repository)
git push -u origin
And then create a new pull request. Once that pull request is merged, I
will explain you how to update this one.
A Git guide for starters I would recommend is
https://rogerdudler.github.io/git-guide.

Thank you for the patch! This works great to retrieve a DHCP lease in TAP mode, but I ran into an issue where the lease would not get automatically renewed.
After an investigation I found that it is related to the IPC_ARP_LIFETIME constant as defined in IPC.h. If the IPC_ARP_LIFETIME >= DHCP_LEASE_TIME / 3 then the OpenVPN connection in TAP mode will get its DHCP lease refreshed, otherwise it will lose its lease. With the default ARP lifetime of 180 seconds and default DHCP lease time of 7200 seconds the TAP connections will always lose their lease.
When it is time to renew the DHCP lease (after DHCP_LEASE_TIME / 3 time has passed) the stack looks roughly as follows:
IPCSendIPv4 IPC.c:1665
IPCSendDhcpRequest IPC.c:964
IPCDhcpRenewIP IPC.c:755
OvsRecvPacket Proto_OpenVPN.c:2509
And an ARP request will be inserted (Raspberry Pi has an OpenVPN connection to SoftEther in TAP mode, where 10.10.10.2 is the Pi and 10.10.10.1 is the Hub):
2019-02-18,10:23:44.173,SID-RASPBERRYPI-[OPENVPN_L2]-2,-,CA9D21C48D80,FFFFFFFFFFFF,0x0806,42,ARPv4,Request,-,-,-,-,-,-,Who has 10.10.10.1? Please Tell CA9D21C48D80(10.10.10.2),-,172.27.1.100,-
2019-02-18,10:23:44.173,SID-SECURENAT-1,SID-RASPBERRYPI-[OPENVPN_L2]-2,5EBCCBFA9A23,CA9D21C48D80,0x0806,42,ARPv4,Response,-,-,-,-,-,-,5EBCCBFA9A23 has 10.10.10.1,-,-,172.27.1.100
This ARP request is always done regardless of whether or not the ARP lifetime has expired. Unfortunately, only when the DHCP renew request is made before the ARP lifetime has expired it will be refreshed. If the DHCP renew request is done after, then it appears that the request gets lost, perhaps because it is not sent once the ARP response is received, but I have not been able to verify this.
After changing the IPC_ARP_LIFETIME to 60 * 60 * 1000 (1 hour), the DHCP lease of OpenVPN connections in TAP mode will correctly get renewed when using the default DHCP lease time of 2 hours.
I was unable to pinpoint exactly where things go wrong. Is it safe to set the ARP lifetime to such a high value? Does SoftEther depend on a low ARP lifetime? It appears that ARP entries related to a session are correctly cleaned up after this session ends, but I'm not sure if ARP entries are copied across multiple servers where such long living stale entries might pose problems?. > Is your certificate's common name set?
The certificate's common name is indeed set.
@ronneke1996's findings correspond with my own. Unfortunately I won't be able to test the proposed workaround / fix until I get back into the office after the holidays, but I am quite confident it will also solve the issue for me.
I appreciate the suggestions, will report back after I can confirm.. I can confirm that adding the client cert ca after the client cert in the cert block indeed works, verification succeeds and the connection is successfully established.
I am not sure if the issue lies within OpenVPN 3, or within SoftEther. As @ronneke1996 mentioned, the verification already fails at the SslCertVerifyCallback stage, before the code snippet shown by @davidebeatrici. The following is pure speculation, but could it be that OpenVPN 3 does not send the root CA together with the client certificate because it is assumed to be known by the server? As an optimisation similar to how browsers do not require the root certificate to be sent because it is assumed to be present locally on the computer? If something like that is the case, perhaps SoftEther could add a check for it.
Thanks again for the suggestions and workaround, this solves the issue for me.. I took a brief look at the tests included with OpenVPN 3 and it looks like the transmission channel is mocked:
OpenVPN/openvpn3/test/ssl/proto.cpp
This would make it difficult to perform an integration test similar to eb64940 without making changes to the OpenVPN 3 code base, as I don't see a way to instruct the OpenVPN 3 client side unit tests to communicate with a separate OpenVPN server (e.g. SoftEther).
Do you have any suggestions?.

gogeekgo:
In my particular case, I'm not concerned about users changing the settings, but having or not having access to things that their particular userid doesn't allow them to access.
The concern is that User A, that may have saved the settings with his userid/password, then User B logs on can then connect to the remote network, using User A's saved vpn credentials.  In my case each user, using the VPN may have different access right levels.  
Right now the work around is that users are not to save the credentials, but I'd rather leave it to chance that users don't accidentally save the password.
. Using the password would prevent User B from using the VPN software.  However in my case,  User B needs to use the VPN software.  If Use A saved his credentials, then User B can then connect using User A's saved credentials.  
Each User really needs to have their VPN settings saved as part of their Windows User Profile and not use a single profile.  Or at least have the option of using a single one or user individual profiles.. Well I was able to test this, and failed to catch the "standard" user part of the Policy. It worked on office's account on the clients server, however the others users all connect via Radius which it doesn't work on.
Is there a comparable Radius setting?.

However, the problem of the TX packets dropped now appears time to time. Now, with this option enabled, when the problem appears, a simple stop/start of the session will solve the problem. However, the trouble continues...

After several days running it, I discovered that after the first time the TX packets dropped start to rise, it never appears after it. So, if you execute one time the stop/restart of the session then you will not show troubles anymore.

So, it's possible some initialization bug?
One workaround is a simple stop/start at first run (or in boot).

I suggest to do some review, or almost include some initial restart option in the config file.
